jyoshu

http://www.cnn.com/2006/US/02/21/funeral.motorcyclists.ap/index.html
 "They call themselves the Patriot Guard Riders, and they are more than 5,000 strong, forming to counter anti-gay protests held by the Rev. Fred Phelps at military funerals.
 
 The church, Westboro Baptist Church, is not affiliated with a larger denomination and is made up mostly of Fred Phelps' extended family members. "
 These Patriot Guard Riders are awesome. A stark contrast to Phelps' hate group.

post_info.post_title: Bikers attend military funerals to oppose Westboro Protesters

Master_Shake

I think this is something everyone on here can get behind. At least I would hope so. Saying that Fred Phelps is an embarrassment to this nation and my home state would be a gross understatement. Sadly, I can't say I'm surprised by this, but I definitely don't think I would have ever predicted it. What he is doing is despicable. And what the Patriot Guard is doing is amazing. I like the sentiment involved in attempting to pass laws against protesting at funerals (although I don't know if they'll hold up in court), I only wish they had felt the same when he was protesting AIDS victims.

 Phelps is one sick pup.

This only goes to show, how two faced some people can be, that it took him protesting military funerals to get people riled up. Where was this outrage when he was picketing gay funerals?
snakespit

I can't stand Phelps and his ilk. I certainly believe in the idea of free speech, but picketing funerals is simply disgusting, and I do not see it as a form of free speech. It is simply meant to draw attention to his merry band of whackos, and stir up trouble. I am in full support of the anti-picketing laws that have been proposed, if they are specific enough to prevent this type of abominable behavior, while protecting free speech for rational people. 
 
 I have been thinking about an idea for a while. Kinda like a pledge drive. Get volunteers who hold a firm dislike of Phelps, and ask them to pledge a dollar or so for every funeral that Phelps' group protests. These pledges to be gathered into lump sums and then donated to either veterans groups or gay rights organizations...depending on which you would prefer to support. Of course all donations would be recorded and reported to Phelps and WBC with our sincere thanks. That way, indirectly through their "protest", they would be supporting the very thing they protest against. What do you think?

 Directly from their website: 
 (I will not link their site here, but a simple google will get you there) 
 
August 20, 1995 - The Night America Bombed Westboro Baptist Church With An IED (Improvised Explosive Device) In A Cowardly Move To Stop WBC's Anti-Gay Gospel Preaching - Thereby Bringing Down The Unmitigated And Irreversible Wrath Of God Upon This Evil Nation, Manifesting Itself In The Daily Bloody IED-Deaths Of American Soldiers In Iraq And Other Places.

 Let's clarify a little. It was a pipe bomb that caused $1691 in damage to a van and $60 damage to a fence. And it was not "America"...it was a solitary 25 y/o college student with an axe to grind. This seems to be only one of the many "reasonings" that Phelps uses to make his case. Others are that America caters to and gives special treatment to homosexuals, the military instituting the don't ask, don't tell policy...etc. 
 
 Phelps thinks that any disaster that befalls the nation or even private American citizens is punishment from god for allowing homosexuals to live among us. In fact, it seems that Phelps feels that just about everyone is going to hell except him and his WBC members. (How convenient...right?). emoticon_rolleyes 
 
 Notable individuals that are going to hell acoording to Phelps: 
 All soldiers in the US military
 Ronald Reagan
 Reggie White
 Pope John Paul II
 Corretta Scott King
 All of the coal miners who died recently
 You...me...
 Canadians
 The Swedish
 W 
 etc etc etc...
 
 It is all guilt by association...even if you yourself are anti-gay. If you serve in our military (or; live in America, Canada, Sweden, are catholic, listen to Elton John, mine coal, fight for civil rights) you support the ideals of a doomed nation that supports gays, ergo you support gays as well, and god kills these people as punishment. 
 
 This man and his sheeple are disrespectful XXXXXX, nothing more.
 
 My overall guess as to why they are hitting funerals so hard is that it causes a high level of outrage, and it brings attention to them. Same reason they protested the funerals of the coal miners, and same reason they protested the 9/11 tragedy. What the majority of Americans see as tragic and sorrowful, they see as an opportunity. I think that's sick.

 You may not be as hate-filled as Phelps. But many who are not as hate filled as Phelps still do not support equality under the law for gay couples. That is Matthew's wish, and if you do not support that then you are a hinderance to what he feels is right and just, regardless of how you feel about him as a person.
 
 It's like saying "I like blue-eyed children just fine, but we need to save money so we aren't going to feed them this week." I am not trying to draw a comparison between forced starvation and legal rights for couples here - but rather trying to elaborate that "how you feel" about a thing does not mean squat if you are supporting action that can harm.

 Like it or not, people have varying views on this subject. Some are willing to give gay people the moon, others feel marriage shouldn't be redefined. Others feel gay relations are wrong, but are willing to give them marriage benefits. Others, civil unions only. Others think they shouldn't be given anything. Like most issues out there, there are not just two ways of looking at it (pro or con). It's a complex issue and as such there are a lot of views out there about it. And then the very issue of harm taking place here is a debate too. There may come a day when it's all cut and dry between only two views, but it's just not that way at this point.
 
 Phelps hates gay people. Of that there can be no question. But other people can and do see the issue of gay pride and gay rights differently than you, and not hate gay people at all. Opposition to gay marriage is not always rooted in hate--in fact many times it's not. That's why Phelps doesn't represent people in general that oppose gay marriage. And because he carries out his protests with a hateful message.
